text.p: Suppose [mathjaxinline]\dim V = 14[/mathjaxinline] and let [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] be a subspace of [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline].

True or false: If we construct a linear transformation [mathjaxinline]T: V \rightarrow \mathbb R^2[/mathjaxinline] such that [mathjaxinline]W = \mathrm{Ker}(T)[/mathjaxinline], then [mathjaxinline]\dim W[/mathjaxinline] must be 12.

font.p: False. If [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is onto, then the rank of [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is 2 and the dimension of [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] must then be [mathjaxinline]14-2 = 12[/mathjaxinline], but there is no reason [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] must be onto. For instance, [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] could send everything to [mathjaxinline]\mathbf{0}[/mathjaxinline], in which case its kernel would be all of [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline].
